sub_title: Researcher & Lecturer Digital Media at Breda University of Applied Sciences
summary:
Qiqi is a dedicated researcher and academic communicator on the topic of simulation gaming and social innovation for sustainability. Currently at Breda University of Applied Sciences (BUas) she is actively doing research in "the Metaverse", "Virtual reality and empathy" and "media invovation & sustainability". 

She is an experienced coordinator in collaborative international research programs, in particular liaising between the Netherlands and China. 

She is also an enthusiastic teacher of game-based interactive learning, and actively practices the e-learning and the MOOC activities. She has professional skills to design and edit high quality introduction movies and teaching materials.

She uses Mandarin and English at academic level, and speaks Dutch fluently.

'description': 'As associate Dean Asia in TIAS, I am responsible to the strategic development of TIAS in China, and other Asian countries. It includes exploring and conducting high quality (collaborative) learning programs for both post-graduate education and company based training as well. 

Research and training Innovative Learning 
I design and research of interactive learning methods to improve students’ motivation and engagement and to continue creative thinking. I explore and further develop new innovative forms of online education, such as the so-called ‘flipping classrooms’, game-based learning, video presentations and virtual classrooms / group discussions and self-learning by using multi-media and gamified elements. 

CSR and Circular Economy
I organize game-based learning classes among Full time international MScBA students to introduce the principles of CSR and Circular Economy. I have developed and organized game-based sessions and courses for universities in China, including Beijing Institute of Technology (BIT), Dalian University of Technology (DUT) and Central University of Finance and Economics (CUFE).', 'title': 'Associate Dean for Asia', 'employment_type': 'Full-time'}]}, {'company': {'id': 1187026, 'name': 'Beijing Institute of Technology', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4E0BAQFE_UMhu5FzlA/company-logo_400_400/0/1519878463769?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=cq9CkYASnxEUm_b4fbXAJCeXHy_xtU5rSzglgXeG4eY', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/beijing-institute-of-technology/', 'employees': {'start': 10001, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Beijing City, China', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2015}}, 'company': 'Beijing Institute of Technology', 'description': 'The International MBA programme (IMBA) in the School of Management and Economics (SME) of BIT aims to prepare MBA students and executive MBAs for leadership and transferable roles in business in emerging globe economics. 

As invited expert, I am responsible for a two-month intensive program of game-based training, to help the participants to develop their strategic thinking and entrepreneurial skills for solving complicated business problems through various game play (both entertainment and serious; analogue and digital games). I also challenge them to work collaboratively to design games that not only can structure the complex problems in the real-world, but also fit the needs of the client organizations, the people who work in the organization and the desired change as well.', 'title': 'Invited expert', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 166529, 'name': 'TU Delft', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C4E0BAQFwaGpwaod9mQ/company-logo_400_400/0/1670699851986?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=x0gehJn4urFszU2u5SdBucc2zlxk3Ja4h8oWEtjCIYo', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/tudelft/', 'employees': {'start': 5001, 'end': 10000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Delft Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}}, 'company': 'Delft University of Technology', 'description': 'From 2011 I am responsible for the KNAW China Exchange program Gaming Multi Actor Policy Making in China and the Netherlands: a Comparative Study of the Strategic Use of Modeling, Simulation & Gaming (MSG) for Integrated Water Management (IWM).

From 2012 I am responsible for the project Gaming Simulation for Integrated Spatial Planning in China.

From 2012 I am working as a scientific coordinator in the Joint Research Centre of Urban Systems & Environment co-established by Delft University of Technology and South China University of Technology. 

I taught the master courses of Cross-Culture Management and Game Design for professionals.

I facilitated game design workshop in ISAGA summer school 2014.', 'title': 'Researcher of Serious Gaming / Lecturer', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'Delft Area, Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'company': 'Delft University of Technology', 'description': 'PhD thesis -- The princess in the Castle: Challenging Serious Game Play for Integrated Policy Analysis and Planning

What are the principles that make societal problems socio-technically complex? And, even more important, how can we support public policymaking in the wake of socio-technical complexity? In my PhD research, I investigated if, why and how serious games and game-like simulations (SGs) can support integrated policy making and planning, especially in relation to managing rivers and oceans. I argue that ‘playful methods’ are particularly suited to surround sophisticated analysis with extensive participation.

My PhD thesis contains many examples and illustrations but centres on: the Climate Game, used in a neighbourhood reconstruction project incorporating climate adaptation measures; The Blokkendoos Planning Kit, used in the Netherlands’ planning project Room for the River for integrated flood management; the MSP Challenge, used to further the development of integrated, eco-system based marine spatial planning. The book provides a de- and re-construction of the ‘principles of play’ that underlying integrated policy analysis. The perceived usefulness of game-like tools in the Dutch and Chinese policy contexts is empirically studied. I concluded in my thesis that serious games for policy-making and planning are powerful methods with largely untapped potential.
